texts.definition: A gameplay period diegetically localized in time and space.
markups: <style="Definition">A gameplay period diegetically localized in time and space.</style>
Some games divide gameplay into several different sequences differentiate by where and when they take place in the game world. Such individual sequences are <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> are a game concept is primarily used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style>, and is explicitly discussed in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Toon">Toon</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Vampire:%20The%20Masquerade">Vampire: The Masquerade</link></style>. The latter defines <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> as “one compact period of time in one location”. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> are examples of more modern <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> which explores alternative power structures by letting players, rather than game masters, create <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style>

Since <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> create rigidly-confined <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style>, many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> exhibits the pattern also. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style> are among those that most often make use of <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> for narrative purposes, with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Grim%20Fandango">Grim Fandango</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Walking%20Dead%20series">Walking Dead series</link></style> as examples of how <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> unlock the narration as gameplay challenges are overcome. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fahrenheit">Fahrenheit</link></style> shows a more complex use of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> in that it shifts which character the player controls between each of them.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed series</link></style> is an example of how <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Action%20Games">Action Games</link></style> can make use of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> to construct more complex narratives. Here, the main historical gameplay is framed by <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> of focused on the modern day character Desmond Miles. Another example of use of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> in the series is from the second game, where players briefly get to play Altaïr from the first game as to get knowledge about how Altaïr's bloodline continued.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> are examples of games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Open%20Worlds">Open Worlds</link></style> and no <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>.

A first option when considering the use of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> is it they should be <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. This subpattern of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> put emphasis on defining all diegetic elements and gameplay actions while not using it allows a focus on <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. Other options relate to where the <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> should be located, which <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should be present, and how long each <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> should last. <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> in which players cannot affect what happens; <style="Link"><link="summary-updates">Summary Updates</link></style> are a subtype of <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> which can provide a prologue or epilogue to other <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style>. The <style="Link"><link="contextualization">Contextualization</link></style> technique introduces <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> within ongoing <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> to enhance these with explanations of former events or foreshadowing of future events.

For <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> the length of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> are more or less determined, either in actual time through <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> or when certain end conditions are met. More flexibility regarding the length of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> can be achieved through the use of <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, which also can improvise <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> according to the need to the players, the narration, or the gameplay. <style="Link"><link="meta-techniques">Meta-Techniques</link></style> can allow both way to communicate meta information during <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> as well as convey information to players that <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> should start or end. One example of this is <style="Link"><link="prompting-techniques">Prompting Techniques</link></style>, which allow both players and <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> to indicate when <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> should end or when new <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> should start.
All <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> which change location from the previous <style="CurrentLink">Scene</style> make use of <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> that are not created through <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> allow details about the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> to be decided or created only when they need to be. This can be used to have both <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="reconfigurable-game-worlds">Reconfigurable Game Worlds</link></style> and opens up for <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fiasco">Fiasco</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Universalis">Universalis</link></style> shows how this can be used to provide players with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> allows designers great control over <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="adventures">Adventures</link></style>. This can for example be used to have <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> (and thereby prevent <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style>) and guarantee breaks in <style="Link"><link="temporal-consistency">Temporal Consistency</link></style> (as for example the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed series</link></style> does). They also allow special focus to be placed on individual <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and can create <style="Link"><link="melodramatic-structures">Melodramatic Structures</link></style> when this is not only done for narrative purposes but also change which <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can act.

They use of <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> can also guarantee that players are exposed to <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="finale-levels">Finale Levels</link></style> can be <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> where narrative arcs are brought to a conclusion (e.g. by fighting <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> are one way of presenting <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> to players. By limiting the area in these where gameplay can occur, <style="CurrentLink">Scenes</style> typically limit or make <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> irrelevant and can be used to structure the development of <style="Link"><link="adventures">Adventures</link></style>.
